heading: Checklists
content: Checklists are organized alphabetically by category. Choose a category to view all checklists included within that category. You can also use Search to search for a specific checklist.

items.label: UFH Anticoagulation Monitoring and Management Algorithm
Insertion of DPC on VA ECMO Procedure
Monitoring and Managing LV Distension on VA ECMO Algorithm
Monitoring Native Cardiac Function on VA ECMO
Switching From CPB to ECMO & VS Procedure

title: Circuit Monitoring
content: Circuits should be monitored during every shift. Use these lists to check the different components of the ECMO circuit. If a checklist is not selectable, it is not selected as part of your ECMO circuit in MY CIRCUIT
keywords: circuit; monitoring; tubing; cannulation; cannula; distal perfusion; insertion site; display unit; bubble sensor; membrane lung; flow meter; heater unit; heater-cooler unit; driving unit; secondary; vent line

title: Component Changes
content: Use this checklist if you need to replace a component within an ECMO circuit. This checklist should be adapted to align with institutional policies, specific patient conditions, and  available resources.

items.label: Identify the need for circuit component replacement

To proceed with whole circuit replacement, all three checks (A, B, and C) are required. Otherwise, do NOT proceed with whole circuit replacement. ELSO does NOT recommend non-urgent replacement of a circuit or circuit component
A. Dysfunctional circuit component: (at least 1 check)
component thrombosis (minor ML clotting not severely impacting with its function excluded (link to ML failure algorithm)
broken component link to circuit disruption algorithm)
C. Replacement of the whole circuit is not indicated (link to whole circuit replacement checklist)
Need to switch to different configurations (e.g., V-AV to VV or VA, VV-V to VV or VV to  VV-V, etc.)
1 experienced intensivist or other ECMO-trained physician
1 experienced ICU nurse to support the patient if as needed
1 experienced ICU nurse to support the patient if as needed
Refresh the team on techniques for air-free circuit connections.
New component (CP, ML, tubing piece, connector)
2 straight connectors adapted to circuit tubing size
Disinfecting solution and/or applicators for tubings preparation (per institutional policy)
Supine the patient in same position as for initiation
Inform him/her and/or their surrogate about the need for replacement, the procedure and potential associated risks (consent)
Increase mechanical ventilation settings as ready to interrupt extracorporeal blood flow on VV ECMO, VVA ECMO, VP ECMO
Increase inotropic/vasopressor support as ready to interrupt extracorporeal blood flow on VA ECMO, VVA ECMO, VP ECMO
Be ready for PRBC transfusion if required
Be ready to perform CPR/ACLS if/as required in case of emergency
If the patient isn't on mechanical ventilation, be ready to manage airways in case of emergency
Check the coagulation profile and increase anticoagulant dosing if deemed necessary

Support the patient if/as needed throughout the procedure. If cardiac  arrest occurs during the procedure and EBF can be promptly restarted, carefully consider if adrenaline  administration is advisable or could be delayed.
Disinfect the portion of tubing which is going to be cut on both sides of the old CP. Allow the solution to act for enough time according to the solution being used.
Go to 0 RPMs and notify the team of the STOP FLOW
Clamp the drainage tubing close to CP
Turn OFF the Sweep Gas Flow
Place two additional clamps approximately 15 cm (6 inches) apart from the previous to isolate the CP from the circuit. If needed, temporarily remove the flowmeter.
Cut the tubings on both sides between the two clamps
Remove the old centrifugal pump from the motor
Connect the outflow of the new pump to the circuit
De-air the new centrifugal pump through the inlet port
Connect the inlet of the CP to the drainage tubing using an air-free technique. If previously removed, reposition and 0 the flowmeter.
Insert the CP into the motor. Check that there are no kinks or traction in the tubings on both sides.
Remove clamp on the drainage tubing
As minimum RPMs are reached to prevent backflow (depending from IFU insert link to almanac section), remove last clamp.
Resume the previous RPMs settings if there are no signs of a return obstruction. (link to return obstruction checklist)
Resume previous Sweep Gas Flow settings
Notify the team of replacement completion

If using a bubble sensor, and it is alarming for the presence of air before the membrane lung, consider removing through the de-airing port of the ML, without stopping the extracorporeal blood flow (link to air entrance algorithm)

title: Coming Off ECMO Emergently
keywords: ECMO; EMERGENTLY; COMING OFF; COMING OFF ECMO EMERGENTLY; TROUBLESHOOTING

items.label: You suspect the need for coming off emergently
Alert and/or activate the ECLS and the ICU teams
Identify the need for coming off emergently
If at least one of the following is true:

Massive air entrance
Go to Panic!: Air in Circuit

Accidental decannulation
Go to Panic!: Accidental Decannulation

Acute circuit thrombosis
Go to Panic!: No Flow

Major circuit disruption
Go to Panic!: Air In Circuit
If weaning is deemed feasible or no other management option is feasible for any reason, proceed to the next step.
Clamp the return tubing to interrupt blood flow
If the cannulas are not functional or no longer required:
Consider surgical repair or hemostatic devices for arterial cannulas
Use mattress suture in the skin for venous cannulas. Compression is not necessary unless there is formation.
If cutdown with ligation into the vessel, it will need surgical decannulation.
If one or more cannulas are still functional or required (also to be used as introducers for alternative cannula)
If coming off due to temporary loss of vascular access due to accidental decannulation, rupture or thrombosis of one cannula, consider:
Clamp the cannula(s) that are still required
Separate the circuit from the cannulas
Flush and clamp the cannulas which are still required
If the circuit is still required:
If the need for coming off is due to temporary loss of vascular access as a result of accidental decannulation, rupture or thrombosis of one cannula, in a scenario of resources constraint:
Keep the circuit functional by recirculating over a bridge OR keep the circuit functional by connecting drainage and return tubing to create a loop.
Flush and clamp the cannula still on site.
If the circuit is NOT functional OR no longer required:
Dispose of the circuit and the cannulas according to hospital protocol.
Clean the ECMO machine according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Optimize conventional respiratory and/or circulatory support as needed
Consider post-decannulation screening of the cannulated vessels for complications
Document the procedure in the patient's chart and include the reason for coming off and timing off
Report the procedure in the ELSO registry

title: Emergency Cart
content: An emergency ECMO cart is used for emergent cannulation, reconfiguration, management of various complications, and decannulation in any non-operating room setting. Review the requirements then select the equipment according to your ECMO needs.
keywords: Equipment; ECMO Cart; Emergency; Checklist; Emergency Checklist; Surgical Instruments; Instruments; Fluids and Medications; Miscellaneous; IV-Related Components; Miscellaneous IV-Related Components; Tubings and Connectors; Cannulas; Cannulation Procedure; DPC Insertion

items.label: Cannulas and Cannulation Procedure (including DPC insertion)
Peripheral drainage cannulas of various sizes/lengths*
Peripheral return cannulas of various sizes/lengths*
Central return cannulas of various sizes/lengths*
Distal perfusion cannula supplies and micropuncture kits
Wired introducer sheaths of various sizes*
Progressive dilators or monodilators of various sizes
Antiseptic solution and/or applicators for skin and tubings preparation (per center institutional policy)
Bite block for transesophageal ultrasound probe
Tubings and Connectors (in sterile single packs)
⅜ tubing pieces for configuration switch/bridge
3-way stopcocks with extension tubing of different lengths (10-100 cm)
Pigtail IV extension tubing with luer lock connectors, several
IPA disinfecting IV port caps (e.g., w/ CHG, alcohol) per center institutional policy
Luer lock syringes in various sizes (2.5 ml to 20 ml)
Additional securement device, if used per center policy
A marker to mark cannula length, if part of center policy
Blood gas analyzer (on top of the cart, regularly tested per manufacturer and institutional policy)
Sterile tubing scissors for emergency circuit exchange or reconfiguration
Sterile suture kits (IF center practice/policy follows the use of sutures for ECMO cannula securement)
Heparin or alternative anticoagulant per center institutional policy

title: Gas Supply Interruption
content: Complete this checklist if a gas supply interruption is suspected.

items.label: Evaluate the Drainage and Return Lines
Evaluate the drainage and return lines using a flashlight
Is there a color difference between the lines entering and exiting the membrane lung (ML)?
If Yes is checked, a gas supply interruption is unlikely. You do not need to complete this checklist
If No is checked, a gas supply interruption is likely. Go to the next step.
If the wall gas and gas blender are in use:
ML is connected to the gas line with
Weaning test is NOT ongoing in VV/VP ECMO
Gas line is connected to the gas blender
Sweep gas flow (SGF) is ON and flowing with
Weaning test is NOT ongoing in VV/VP ECMO
Fraction of Oxygen in the SGF (FsO₂) is above 21 and appropriate for the specific patient/configuration
If the O₂ cylinder or air/O₂ cylinders are in use:
Membrane Lung (ML) is connected to the gas line with
Weaning test is NOT ongoing in VV/VP ECMO
Gas line is connected to the cylinder
Gas line is connected to the Y connector*
Line after the Y connector is connected to air/O₂ cylinders*
If any boxes are unchecked, go to Cause is Detected.
If all boxes have been checked, go to Cause is NOT Detected.
If there is an empty cylinder with NO other gas source available, consider blowing through the gas line inlet of the ML
Disconnect or cut the gas line between the filter and gas source
Confirm the color difference between the tubing entering and exiting the ML by using a flashlight
Confirm that gas exchange though pre/post-ML blood sampling is consistent with the device and gas blender settings*
Increase FsO₂ to 100% until the issue is resolved
Confirm that there is a persistent lack of color difference between the tubing entering and exiting the ML by using a flashlight
Confirm that gas exchange though pre/post-ML blood sampling is NOT consistent with the device and gas blender settings
Membrane Lung disruption or failure is likely. Go to the Membrane Lung Failure checklist.

title: Handoff (Multidisciplinary)
keywords: Handoff; Multidisciplinary Team; Documentation; Patient Assessment; Basic Patient Information; POCT; Laboratory Data; ECMO Assessment

items.label: YES—Multi-drug resistant (MDR), extended-drug resistant (EDR), or pan-drug resistant (PDR) microorganism isolated
Size and length for each cannula
Dressing type, status, and latest replacement
Size and length for each cannula
Dressing type, status, and latest replacement
Fraction of O₂ in the sweep gas flow (FsO₂)
Set heater unit (HU) or heater-cooler unit (HCU) water temperature
Set servo regulations, if there are any
Presence of clots or fibrin strands
Ratio of PaO₂ and Fraction of inspired O₂ (FiO₂)
Arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO₂)
Timing of latest test(s) and next one(s)
Mixed O<sup>2</sup> saturation (SvO<sup>2</sup>) or Central venous O<sup>2</sup> saturation (ScvO<sup>2</sup>)
If any boxes are checked, open Notes and enter the date performed and any results available including antibiogram for each swab or test.

Ongoing sedation
If checked, open Notes and list the medication(s), dosage, route, and vacation duration, if any.

Ongoing analgesia
If checked, open Notes and add the medication(s), dosage, and route.

Latest neuroimaging tests
If checked, open Notes and add the type, date, and result.

Need for inotrope(s)
If checked, open Notes and add the type and dosage.

Need for vasopressor(s)
If checked, open Notes and add the type and dosage.

Need for vasodilator(s)
If checked, open Notes and add the type and dosage.

Need for pulmonary vasodilator(s)
If checked, open Notes and add the type, dosage, and route.
Anticoagulant type, dose, and recent changes or route
Anticoagulant on hold, including rationale and timing
Renal replacement therapy (RRT) with configuration and settings, including regional anticoagulation if ongoing

Enteral nutrition
If checked, open Notes and add the type, dose, route, NG/NJ/OG/OJ/PEG/PEJ.

Parenteral nutrition
If checked, open Notes and add the type, dose, and route for parenteral nutrition.

Others
If checked, open Notes and list any other relevant medications.
If Yes is checked, open Notes and add the type, rationale, and results from recent consults and/or exams.

Bleeding events
If checked, open Notes and enter the site, severity, and management of the bleeding.

Thrombosis (site, severity, management)
If checked, open Notes and enter the site, severity, and management of the thrombosis.

Pressure injuries
If checked, open Notes and enter the site, severity, and dressings of the pressure injuries.

Any other relevant team member
If any of the options are checked, open Notes and enter the individual’s name, role, and contact information.

Latest monitoring completed by responsible ECMO specialist or perfusionist
End-of-life preferences:
Do not resuscitate order (DNR) if applicable in the country
Extracorporeal Life Support Organization (ELSO) registry last updated

title: Insertion of DPC on VA ECMO Procedure

items.label: Go to the Gas Supply Interruption checklist. Once a gas supply interruption is ruled out, return to and complete this checklist.
Evaluate the Membrane Lung (ML) Pressures and Blood Flow

Calculate pressure drop or delta P
ΔP = PPRE-ML - PPOST-ML
Open Notes to record the value.

Calculate membrane lung resistances (MLR)
MLR = ΔP/EBF
Open Notes to record the value.
Check your values against the standard pressures for the device, listed in the Almanac [link?].
Values are excessive compared to standard pressures
There are progressive or acute increases in ΔP and MLR compared to the previous evaluation
There is a progressive increase in rotations per minute (RPMs) to maintain target EBF
If any boxes are checked, ML dysfunction or failure is likely.
Consider ML or circuit exchange [Circuit Change (Emergent and Elective)]
Consider coming off ECMO emergently if preferable for the patient [Coming Off ECMO Emergently]
If none of the boxes are checked, continue to the next step.
Flush the gas line (Link to ML recruitment checklist)
Maximize sweep gas flow (SGF) and O₂ fraction in the sweep gas flow (FsO₂)
Sample the blood before and after the ML to assess the O₂ uptake
Is there a decreased O₂ uptake?
Is the V’O₂ < 100-150 ml/min ? (link to calculator)
Is the PPRE-ML CO₂ – PPOST-ML CO₂ < 10 mmHg?
If at least one YES without an alternative explanation, excluding a gas supply interruption, ML dysfunction or failure is likely.
Consider performing a Circuit Change or Coming Off ECMO if it’s preferable for the patient.
If NO, continue to the next step.
If the answer is YES to either without an alternative explanation, consider ML or circuit change.
Are TEG or ROTEM suggesting signs of consumptive coagulopathy?

title: Return Obstruction
keywords: Return Obstruction; Obstruction; Evaluation; Assessment; Return Cannulas; Cannulas; Kinking; Cannula Displacement; Cannula Misplacement; Clot; Cannula Clot; Thrombosis; Cannula Placement

items.label: Evaluate Membrane Lung Pressures and Blood Flow

Calculate pressure drop or delta pressure (ΔP)
ΔP = PPRE-ML – PPOST-ML
Open Notes to record the value.

Calculate membrane lung resistances (MLR)
MLR = ΔP – EBF (optional)
Open Notes to record the value.
Is there a progressive or acute increase in PPRE-ML with significantly decreased ΔP and MLR (optional), compared to the previous evaluation?
Is there a progressive increase in revolutions per minute (RPMs) to maintain the target EBF or an acute decrease in EBF with the same RPMs?
If you checked YES for either question, a return obstruction is likely. Go to Assess the Circuit.
If you checked NO for both questions, a return obstruction is unlikely.
Consider alternative cause(s) for observed signs that led to the  original suspicion of a return obstruction.
Check for clamp (at initiation), kinking, or compression as a result of:

• The patient's leg
  • A cart wheel
  • A bed wheel
  • The bed sides
  • Any devices placed on the bed
  • A tubing holder that’s too strict
Release or remove the obstruction from the return tubing
Check the EBF and PPOST-ML to verify a full return to effective ECMO support with no residual signs of impaired pump outflow
The cause of the obstruction has been detected and resolved. No other steps are needed.
Go to Assess the Return Cannula.
If using a peripheral VA ECMO femoral return cannula in the ECMO circuit:
Check for evidence of vibrations of the return tubing
Evaluate return tubing using the flashlight test for any evidence of a clot or thrombus, particularly if connector(s) are present
Has the clot or thrombus been detected?
if NO go to termination B
if NO go to termination C
if NO clot/thrombus detected proceed in evaluation
Evaluate the return cannula for clamp (at initiation) or kinking
If an obstruction is detected on the external portion of the return cannula, release or remove.
If kinking is involved, wired port of the cannula, if any, check for the absence of residual or permanent kink(s).
If the cause of the obstruction has been detected and resolved:
Check the EBF and PPOST-ML to verify a full return to effective ECMO support with no residual signs of impaired pump outflow.
If there is a residual kink or a clot or thrombus is detected, evaluate if replacement of the return cannula is required.
If YES, insert a new return cannula (link to cannulation procedure), switch the circuit to the new cannula and remove the old cannula.
If NO, go to the Coming Off ECMO Emergently checklist.
If the obstruction is NOT detected:
Check the cannula position with an ultrasound, fluoroscopy, and/or x-ray according to the technique more readily available and according to local preferences
Is there misplacement at initiation or displacement of the return cannula?
YES, there is misplacement or displacement of the return cannula.
Adjust the return cannula position and verify the proper positioning. The cause of the obstruction has been identified and resolved.
Check the EBF and PPOST-ML to verify a full return to effective ECMO support with no residual signs of impaired pump outflow
Evaluate if replacement of the return cannula is required.
If YES, insert a new return cannula (link to cannulation procedure), switch the circuit to the new cannula and remove the old cannula.
If NO, go to the Coming Off ECMO Emergently checklist.
NO, there is NOT misplacement or displacement of the return cannula.
Check the cannula patency with an ultrasound,  fluoroscopy, or CT according to the technique more readily available and according to local preferences
Cannula clot or thrombosis is detected.
Evaluate if replacement is required (patient non-weanable/ECLS not futile/alternative access available)
Insert new return cannula (link to cannulation procedure)
Coming Off ECMO Emergently
No clot or thrombosis is detected involving the return cannula. Go to the next step, Evaluate the Patient.
Look for signs of increased afterload to the blood return.
If you have a VA ECMO configuration
If there is a femoral return cannula, exclude the first significant improvement of left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF)

If NO or if any other VA ECMO cannulation strategy, check with ultrasound and/or fluoroscopy/CT according to the technique more readily available and according to local preferences for signs of arterial dissection
If you have a VAV ECMO configuration

If NO or if any other VA ECMO cannulation strategy, check with ultrasound and/or fluoroscopy/CT according to the technique more readily available and according to local preferences for signs of arterial dissection
If you have a VV ECMO or VP configuration
Exclude tension pneumothorax, cardiac tamponade, or vascular thrombosis in the vessel or chamber where the return cannula is located
If any clinical issue is detected, try to fix it as it is likely causing the return obstruction.
